ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned so much about the overlap between visual perception and social cognition that I had never considered before. Also definitely learned how to read research critically.
Learnt a lot on social perception, and how to critique psychological papers (being sceptical of methodologies, for instance, even when articles are published in renowned journals).
Insight into evaluating and discussing academic papers related to social perception critically.

I've learned a lot on how to read STEM papers and not believe everything that research papers tell you. The ability to scrutinize a paper is a very important skill in research, and this is one of the few classes where you can learn it. And of course, you get a good understanding on what the recent research/debates are in visual perception and its relation with social attributes.
Read papers about social cognition and visual perception
learning diverse methodological techniques and looking at previous studies with a critical point of view

By taking "Social Perception", I learned to critically read research papers and improved my understanding of their format. I also gained a solid comprehension of the main topics of social cognition research in the present moment, and was able to discuss the nuances of such topics in depth.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: fascinating readings every week, super cool topics and well organised flow of course material
weaknesses: sometimes too many papers to discuss in seminar, discussion was also a little erratic, as Prof. Scholl would provide a lot of background context so that there was not always enough time to actually engage in a discussion (there was also an overall sense that each question has an "empirical" right answer, which i think may have stifled people's questions and thoughts a little).

The discussion format allows for a lot of flexibility and student input, not just within each class but with topics and themes as a whole. It's really student-driven which is great for those that are highly interested in the topic. Because of this flexibility I don't think each time this course is taught is the same, so I'd say it'd be hard to point out a specific improvement although perhaps some more regular feedback regarding our performance would be useful.
The seminar is very engaging, and has a nice atmosphere where you can speak up when you want to.
Interesting subject matter. But the teaching was not very engaging. Felt more like a lecture punctuated by long-winded and hardly related comments.

I had mixed feelings about the amount and type of readings. For one, I really enjoyed all the materials we have read for this class  both the bad/fake and good papers. But from time to time, it did feel a bit too much. Even at times when the readings seemed brief in the first blush, they turned out to be quite dense and sometimes I ended up spending my entire day reading these papers and having to save the response for another time. That being said, however, I am very glad that I had the chance to read all the materials, even the ones that ended up being too technical (especially the Chang & Tsao, 2017 paper) for me to understand. I can see the reasons why each of them were relevant to our discussions. But sometimes I wished that there would actually be more time that we spend discussing these papers, because I often felt like we ended up discussing some experiment demonstrations that you have shown us in the board or digressed from the topic.

I honestly found the course format overall extremely good. The main strength of the class is that it opens a space for students interested in Cognitive Science to openly discuss social cognition in an engaging way. We were able to question the validity of certain published research papers, and we were encouraged to propose ideas/pose questions that open doors towards future studies with novel methodologies.

Strengths: very interesting content

Weakness: discussion a little bit too geared to Professor Scholl's opinions. I think it would have been nicer if there were not so much bias involved in the content we discussed

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely, super fascinating topics and there's not really another class like it.
Yes! Great class with lots of interesting readings and opportunities to learn from Prof. Scholl. Social perception is a fascinating topic.

If you enjoy discussion-based seminars on psychology/cognitive science then totally. The topics covered are broad and fascinating to pretty much anyone into these sorts of fields and disciplines, and are adjustable based on student interest. Professor Scholl is also a highly knowledgeable and engaging instructor that makes the content really click.
YES, if you are interested in perception, this is a very good course for you to be introduced to numerous research in the field.
No. Interesting subject but not taught in an interesting way.
Yes, this is a very unique and fun class, and it was probably my favorite psychology class I've taken at Yale.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, especially if that student likes to actively participate in class and engage in discussions with peers from diverse backgrounds and opinions. Social Perception allows students with multiple interests to delve into topics of social cognition and prompts students to view scientific research in a critical manner.
